reviews.review: Hey Gordon, it's me! About that beer I owe ya! Blah blah blah blah blah whatever

[h1]A short, but still fun romp through Half-Life's addictive gameplay[/h1]

Half-Life: Blue Shift is a short expansion for Half-Life that takes you into the perspective of Barney Calhoun, a security guard at Black Mesa, and later a main character of Half-Life 2. This expansion takes place during the same Black Mesa Incident that Half-Life, Half-Life: Opposing Force, and Half-Life Decay all take place in.

Sadly, while gameplay is still a blast, the most notable thing about this expansion for Half-Life is its relatively short length. Someone who has played other games in the series should have no problem beating this expansion in around 3 Hours. Unlike Opposing Force, this expansion does not include any new enemies, weapons, or expansive set pieces making Blue Shift seem somewhat bland. 

The reasoning for Half-Life: Blue Shift's lack of content and length is due to it's reason for existing at all: It was meant as a short addon for the cancelled Sega Dreamcast version of Half-Life. Thankfully, after the Dreamcast version of Half-Life was scrapped, we received Blue Shift for PC, which also brought the new HD weapon and character models from the console versions of Half-Life.

Despite its lack of content, short length, and rough upbringing; Half-Life Blue Shift is still definitely worth picking up on sale or as part of a bundle. Fans who enjoyed the main campaign of Half-Life or its expansion Opposing Force, will enjoy Half-Life Blue Shift for sharing the same addictive combat loop as its predecessors.

Never finish Half-Life or played Opposing Force but honestly enjoy playing through this despite how super short it was and considering that this was originally an exclusive add on for the cancelled Dreamcast version, the levels do feel like they were made for a console controller in mind. 

Now I should REALLY finish Half-Life or play Opposing Force...one of these days at least üëÄ
Nice little back story into Barney. Shame he was silent. some good puzzles. only playing it a few years late.

I‚Äôm gonna say this. This expansion is short. Really short. While I do recommend that you play it, just play it once and that‚Äôs it. It was originally gonna be a side story for the cancelled Dreamcast port of Half-Life, but it was put in PC. It‚Äôs fun, just not as good as Op4. Can be boring when Rosenburg is talking. Like I said, play it once and you‚Äôre done.
Beating quota

Very short Half-Life expansion pack developed by Gearbox Software where you play and view the story of the first Half-Life game through the eyes of Barney Calhoun.

If it was slightly longer, it could‚Äôve been a better expansion pack (To me, this game felt like it was 2 hours long). If you aren‚Äôt a big fan of the Half-Life series, you should probably wait for the next Steam sale and give Half-Life: Blue Shift a try.

Despite it being shorter and smaller scale compare to Half-Life, this is a fun FPS from the perspective of the legendary Barney Calhoun during the Resonance Cascade incident. It feels more arcade-ish and chaotic compare to the careful tactical play that you'll usually do in Half-Life.

A good side story to the main Half-Life game. Graphic may be too old for these days, but it was part of the legend at the time. Looking forward to see a remake like Black Mesa: Definitive Edition soon.
Cool game

Shortest from Half Life anthology, but still good. This time you play as security guard named Barney Callhoon.
Also it have much better ending than OG Half Life and Opposing Force.

While it doesn't expand the mechanics, enemies, or weaponry of [i]Half-Life[/i] in the same way that [i]Opposing Force[/i] did, [i]Blue Shift[/i] is still another solid 2 or 3 hours of [i]Half-Life[/i] content and it's where Barney himself became [i]the[/i] Barney Calhoun. You get to meet one or two fun new characters and the level design is very good, with a particularly spacious sense of architecture. The combat encounters are thoughtful and well-paced as you would want from [i]Half-Life 1[/i] content, and there are some clever puzzles along the way. You can't go wrong with more [i]Half-Life[/i].

If you enjoyed the original then I'd highly suggest this one. It's only about 1.30 hrs long or about 2-3 hrs long on the first play through. It might be short but it's still more Half-Life to play. It also has lots of marines and they're basically the main enemy, so if you like gunning down lots of marines then you should get this. It also has more characters/story moments than the original (later in-game), which can or cannot be ideal based on your opinion. It could've used a boss of some sort, maybe a mini gun wielding marine who could be supported by a squad or a helicopter as least.  Overall I'd recommend giving this a try at least since it's only $5.

Coming off of Half-Life and Opposing Force, it's easy to play through Blue Shift and be somewhat underwhelmed. The very short length and lack of anything new being brought to the table makes it feel more like an official mod than a full-on expansion. That said, what is there is still classic Half-Life, and I still enjoy playing it. Seeing events from Barney's point of view will always have its appeal, even if I don't revisit his perspective as often as the others.
Basically more Half-Life.

Excelente juego, muy entretenido.

[h1]Rating[/h1]
8/10

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Unlike Opposing Force, Blue Shift doesn't really bring anything new to the table, aside from being able to play as one of the security guards. But I still recommend getting it, if you liked Half-Life and Opposing Force.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ Good soundtrack.
+ Good replay value.
+ Great enemy variety.
+ There's plenty of areas to explore for supplies.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Enemies are bullet sponges on Hard difficulty.
- Lacks weapon variety compared to both Half-Life and Opposing Force.
